user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_bd_sync:
```c
static int lfs_bd_sync(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, bool validate) {
    lfs_cache_drop(lfs, rcache);

    int err = lfs_bd_flush(lfs, pcache, rcache, validate);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    err = lfs->cfg->sync(lfs->cfg);
    LFS_ASSERT(err <= 0);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_bd_sync:
typedef struct lfs_cache {
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_size_t size;
    uint8_t *buffer;
} lfs_cache_t
...
static inline void lfs_cache_drop(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_cache_t *rcache) {
    // do not zero, cheaper if cache is readonly or only going to be
    // written with identical data (during relocates)
    (void)lfs;
    rcache->block = LFS_BLOCK_NULL;
}
...
static int lfs_bd_flush(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, bool validate) {
    if (pcache->block != LFS_BLOCK_NULL && pcache->block != LFS_BLOCK_INLINE) {
        LFS_ASSERT(pcache->block < lfs->block_count);
        lfs_size_t diff = lfs_alignup(pcache->size, lfs->cfg->prog_size);
        int err = lfs->cfg->prog(lfs->cfg, pcache->block,
                pcache->off, pcache->buffer, diff);
        LFS_ASSERT(err <= 0);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        if (validate) {
            // check data on disk
            lfs_cache_drop(lfs, rcache);
            int res = lfs_bd_cmp(lfs,
                    NULL, rcache, diff,
                    pcache->block, pcache->off, pcache->buffer, diff);
            if (res < 0) {
                return res;
            }

            if (res != LFS_CMP_EQ) {
                return LFS_ERR_CORRUPT;
            }
        }

        lfs_cache_zero(lfs, pcache);
    }

    return 0;
}
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
int err = lfs->cfg->prog(lfs->cfg, pcache->block,
                pcache->off, pcache->buffer, diff);
explanation:
Other code fragments in the provided snippets were not flagged because they already use const where appropriate or clearly require mutable pointers:

- The configuration pointer inside the lfs_t structure is already declared const, so no further const-qualification is needed there.

- Several operations in the code base explicitly modify cache state or cache contents (e.g. zeroing cache buffers, updating cache metadata fields, writing data via the prog callback). Those operations require writable (non-const) pointers to buffer/cache structures, so those places are not candidates for adding "const" qualifiers.

- Calls to callbacks on the config (sync/prog) use the config pointer as intended; the config pointer is const-qualified in the structure and therefore does not need changes.

I focused the investigation on the places where non-const pointer types are passed into functions or stored in structures but may be used read-only (or could reasonably be const-qualified) — these fragments are listed above for further review. No other fragments in the supplied code appear to be missed or appropriate for const-qualification given the shown operations.
